deliberation: Considered whether the instructions are purely literal grooming or a symbolic sign‑act. The sword as razor is strange but not clearly metaphorical; however the shaving and careful weighing/dividing of the hair clearly functions symbolically for the people’s fate in the chapter’s development, so I treat the shaving/dividing of hair as an enacted metaphorical sign.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהַעֲבַרְתָּ עַל־רֹאשְׁךָ וְעַל־זְקָנֶךָ ... וְלָקַחְתָּ לְךָ מֹאזְנֵי מִשְׁקָל וְחִלַּקְתָּם
instances.english_text: pass it over your head and beard. Then take scales and divide the hair.
target: the population of Jerusalem and their divided fates under judgment
vehicle: Ezekiel’s shaved hair carefully weighed and divided into portions
ground: being cut off, reduced, separated and apportioned, indicating loss and differentiated outcomes
shared pattern of removal and division
conceptual mapping of physical cutting to social/historical destruction
posture: prophetic portrayal of God’s severe but ordered judgment on Jerusalem
instances.explanation: Ezekiel’s shaved and weighed hair functions as an enacted metaphor (symbolic sign‑act) for the people of Jerusalem being cut off and divided into distinct groups according to their coming judgments.

deliberation: The verse continues the hair sign‑act: burning, striking with the sword, and scattering hairs. These actions symbolize different fates of the people (later made explicit in v.12). In addition, the phrase “scatter a third to the wind” is an idiomatic metaphor for total dispersion.

instances.hebrew_text: שְׁלִשִׁית בָּאוּר תַּבְעִיר בְּתּוֹךְ הָעִיר ... וְלָקַחְתָּ אֶת־הַשְּׁלִשִׁית תַּכֶּה בַחֶרֶב סְבִיבוֹתֶיהָ
instances.english_text: destroy a third part in fire in the city, take a third and strike it with the sword all around the city
target: the different segments of Jerusalem’s population and their various deaths in the coming judgment
vehicle: thirds of Ezekiel’s hair burned in the midst of the city and struck with a sword around it
portions of hair subjected to fire and sword
bodily hair manipulated in a ritual/action scene
ground: correspondence between parts of the hair and subgroups of people, each subjected to a particular mode of destruction (fire or sword)
shared pattern of proportional division and violent removal
mapping of physical treatment of objects to fates of people
posture: presentation of divine judgment as carefully apportioned yet devastating
didactic use of visual symbolism to warn the audience
instances.explanation: The threefold treatment of the shaved hair—burning in the city and striking with the sword around it—is an enacted metaphor mapping portions of hair to portions of the population and their respective destruction by fire and sword.

instances.english_text: and scatter a third to the wind
target: the future dispersion of one third of the people of Jerusalem
vehicle: hairs being scattered to the wind in every direction
ground: loss of cohesion, directionless spreading, and vulnerability to forces beyond control
shared idea of total, uncontrollable dispersal
conceptualization of exile as scattering by wind
posture: emphasis on the totality and helplessness of the coming dispersion
heightened rhetorical warning to the audience
instances.explanation: The idiom “scatter to the wind” uses the image of particles blown away in all directions to describe the total dispersion and vulnerability of the surviving third of the people.

deliberation: This continues the sign‑act, now focusing on a small number of hairs kept and bound in Ezekiel’s skirts. Within the ongoing symbolic framework, these few hairs stand metaphorically for a preserved remnant of the people.

instances.english_text: a few [hairs] in number and tie them up in your skirts
target: the small remnant of Israelites preserved through judgment
faithful or spared minority within the nation
vehicle: a small counted number of hairs bound securely in the prophet’s garment-skirts
carefully kept remnants of shaved hair
ground: smallness, selectiveness, and protective keeping of a tiny portion from a larger mass
shared sense of being set apart and safeguarded
conceptual link between preserved hair and preserved people
posture: acknowledgment that divine judgment includes preservation of a remnant
instances.explanation: The counted few hairs tied in Ezekiel’s skirts act as a metaphorical sign of a small remnant of people whom God will preserve in the midst of widespread destruction.

deliberation: The verse describes taking some of the preserved hairs and burning them so that “from there a fire shall go out upon all the house of Israel.” The burning of some of the remnant hairs continues the hair/people metaphor, and the ‘fire’ that goes out functions as a metaphor for a spreading, consuming judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִשְׁלַכְתָּ אֹתָם אֶל־תּוֹךְ הָאֵשׁ וְשָׂרַפְתָּ אֹתָם בָּאֵשׁ מִמֶּנּוּ תֵצֵא־אֵשׁ אֶל־כׇּל־בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: cast them into the fire, and burn them in the fire. From this a fire shall go out upon the whole House of Israel.
target: the further judgment arising within Israel, even among a preserved group
internal source and spread of national calamity
vehicle: some of the preserved hairs being thrown into a fire that then sends out flames
fire starting from a small source and spreading
ground: a small core becoming the origin of a wider destructive blaze, symbolizing judgment originating within the community and affecting all
shared notion of contagion and spread from a remnant nucleus
mapping of literal burning to the expansion of punitive events
posture: portrayal of judgment as both originating inside the community and inevitably spreading
underscoring the severity and pervasiveness of divine punishment
instances.explanation: Burning some of the remnant hairs so that a fire goes out upon all Israel combines the ongoing hair=people symbolism with the image of a fire spreading, metaphorically depicting a further outbreak and spread of judgment among the nation.

deliberation: The verse is mostly literal geography and theology. However, “this Jerusalem” functions metonymically for the city’s inhabitants and polity, not just the physical site.

instances.english_text: I set this Jerusalem in the midst of nations
target: the people and political-religious entity centered in Jerusalem
covenant community located in the capital city
ground: the city stands for its residents, leadership, and religious life
standard city-for-inhabitants association
conventional metonymic relation between place and people
posture: emphasis on Jerusalem’s central, exemplary role among nations
instances.explanation: The name “Jerusalem” is used metonymically for the community that lives there and bears responsibility for its vocation among the nations.

deliberation: Here ‘she’ (Jerusalem) is said to have rebelled and acted wickedly, using a feminine singular pronoun and verb for the city. This treats Jerusalem (the city/place) as a moral agent, combining metonymy (city for people) and personification.

instances.english_text: But she rebelled against My rules and My laws, acting more wickedly than the nations
target: the inhabitants and leadership of Jerusalem who broke God’s laws
collective moral behavior of the city’s populace
vehicle: Jerusalem portrayed as a woman who rebels and acts wickedly
ground: the city’s people corporately exhibit willful disobedience, like a rebellious person
shared traits of intentional defiance and moral responsibility
conceptualization of a collective as a single person
instances.explanation: The city is personified as a woman who rebels against God’s rules, a metonymic and personifying way of speaking about the people’s collective apostasy.

deliberation: The verse is largely straightforward accusation: Israel has not walked in God’s statutes nor even in those of the nations. Expressions of surpassing the nations in wickedness can be rhetorically strong but are not clearly non-literal figures here; no distinct metaphor, simile, idiom, or hyperbole stands out as such.

God says, “I am against you” and “I will execute judgments in your midst in the sight of the nations.” While judicial terminology is evocative, it reflects the covenantal legal framework and is not clearly being used figuratively in contrast to some other literal description. I do not isolate a distinct figurative expression here.
The claim that God will do what He has never done and will never do again is a strong superlative; contextually it functions as hyperbolic emphasis on the unparalleled nature of the coming judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעָשִׂיתִי בָךְ אֵת אֲשֶׁר לֹא־עָשִׂיתִי וְאֵת אֲשֶׁר־לֹא־אֶעֱשֶׂה כָּמֹהוּ עוֹד
instances.english_text: I will do among you what I have never done, and the like of which I will never do again.
target: the severity and uniqueness of the impending judgment on Jerusalem
vehicle: language of absolute, unprecedented, and never-to-be-repeated action
ground: intended sense of extreme uniqueness and severity, rather than a strictly statistical comparison with all events in history
shared emphasis on exceptionality
use of absolute terms to communicate unmatched seriousness
posture: heightened warning meant to shock and impress the audience
instances.explanation: The statement that nothing like this has ever been done, nor will be again, is hyperbolic language stressing the exceptional horror of the coming judgment.

deliberation: Cannibalism of parents and children is a horrific but, in siege contexts, a literal possibility in prophetic literature. However, the phrase “I will scatter all your survivors to every wind” is a conventional idiomatic metaphor for total dispersion.

instances.english_text: and I will scatter all your survivors in every direction [lit. to every wind].
target: the comprehensive dispersal of the surviving people of Jerusalem
vehicle: particles being scattered to every wind
material chaff/dust blown about by winds
ground: imagery of being blown apart, directionless, and unable to remain gathered
shared sense of complete, indiscriminate dispersal
conceptual mapping of exile as scattering by wind
posture: stress on the inescapable and total nature of the coming dispersion
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘scatter … to every wind’ uses the picture of dust or chaff blown by all the winds to depict the total and helpless dispersion of the remaining survivors.

deliberation: The verse speaks of defiling the sanctuary (literal cultic language) and of God not sparing or having compassion. The expression “my eye will not spare” uses bodily imagery for divine compassion, an anthropomorphic metaphor for pity withheld.

instances.english_text: I in turn will shear [you] away and my eye will not spare.
target: God’s withholding of pity from the people in judgment
vehicle: an eye that has or withholds compassion/sparing
human bodily organ associated with pitying gaze
ground: link between the act of visually regarding someone and the decision to show mercy
shared idea of compassion expressed (or not) through the eye
anthropomorphic mapping of human affect to divine action
posture: portrayal of God as resolute and unsparing in judgment
rhetorical reinforcement of the seriousness of defiling the sanctuary
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘my eye will not spare’ uses the human image of an eye that either looks with pity or refuses to, as a metaphorical, anthropomorphic way of saying that God will show no compassion.

deliberation: The verse applies the thirds scheme directly to the people: pestilence/famine, sword, and scattering. The phrase “scatter the third to every wind” reprises the idiomatic metaphor for total dispersion, and the ‘unsheathed sword after them’ continues the image of relentless pursuit in judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהַשְּׁלִישִׁית לְכׇל־רוּחַ אֱזָרֶה וְחֶרֶב אָרִיק אַחֲרֵיהֶם
instances.english_text: and I will scatter one-third in every direction [lit. to every wind] and will unsheathe the sword after them.
target: the fate of the last third of the population: dispersed and relentlessly pursued by violence
vehicle: people scattered to the winds and chased by an unsheathed sword
chaff blown by wind and fugitives pursued by a drawn sword
natural dispersal and military pursuit imagery
ground: complete dislocation coupled with inescapable, continuing danger
shared sense of exposure and pursuit with no refuge
mapping of exile plus violence to being blown and hunted
posture: emphasis on the thoroughness and persistence of divine judgment
instances.explanation: The idiom of scattering to every wind together with the image of a drawn sword pursuing them depicts the dispersed third as utterly scattered and yet still under lethal pursuit.

deliberation: God’s ‘anger’ and ‘fury’ are described as being spent, brought to rest, and leading to God’s being ‘comforted/appeased.’ This is anthropopathic language in which divine wrath is conceptualized in human emotional and quasi-physical terms.

instances.hebrew_text: וְכָלָה אַפִּי וַהֲנִחוֹתִי חֲמָתִי בָּם וְהִנֶּחָמְתִּי
instances.english_text: I will vent all My anger and satisfy My fury upon them; and I will be comforted.
target: God’s decision to bring judgment to completion and then cease from wrath
vehicle: human anger and fury that can be expended, brought to rest, and followed by a sense of being comforted/appeased
emotional and quasi-physical processes in humans
ground: the idea that wrath reaches a point of completion and then subsides, akin to human anger that cools after expression
shared notion of emotional tension being released
anthropopathic mapping from human affect to divine action
posture: portraying divine judgment as passionate yet ultimately bounded and purposeful
underscoring both severity and finality of the judgment
instances.explanation: The verse uses human emotional metaphors—anger expended and resultant ‘comfort’—to describe God’s wrath and its cessation in terms understandable from human experience.

deliberation: The language of making Jerusalem a ‘ruin’ and ‘reproach’ among the nations is conceptually strong but straightforward: it describes literal devastation and public disgrace “in the sight of every passerby.” No distinct figurative expression (metaphor, idiom, or hyperbole) stands out beyond normal descriptive usage.
Jerusalem is said to become ‘a mockery and a derision, a warning (mûsār) and a horror’ to the nations. Being ‘a warning/instruction’ is a metaphor: the city’s fate itself serves as an object-lesson.

instances.hebrew_text: חֶרְפָּה וּגְדוּפָה מוּסָר וּמְשַׁמָּה לַגּוֹיִם אֲשֶׁר סְבִיבוֹתָיִךְ
instances.english_text: you shall be a mockery and a derision, a warning and a horror, to the nations round about you
target: the exemplary, didactic function of Jerusalem’s judgment for surrounding nations
Israel’s fate as a moral lesson
ground: observers learn from what happens, being deterred or instructed by it
shared notion of an event functioning as a moral warning
mapping from abstract pedagogy to a concrete historical catastrophe
posture: framing the judgment as not only punitive but also educational for the nations
broad theological perspective on Israel’s role
instances.explanation: Describing Jerusalem as ‘a warning (mûsār)’ to the nations metaphorically portrays its devastation as an instructional example, a living cautionary tale for others.

deliberation: Two clear metaphors appear: (1) ‘arrows of famine’ portrays famine as deadly arrows shot by God; (2) ‘break the staff of bread’ is a known idiom presenting bread as a staff that supports life. Both are distinct figures.

instances.hebrew_text: חִצֵּי הָרָעָב הָרָעִים בָּהֶם אֲשֶׁר הָיוּ לְמַשְׁחִית
instances.english_text: the deadly arrows of famine against those doomed to destruction
target: the destructive operation of famine as an instrument of God’s judgment
vehicle: arrows shot at those marked for destruction
ground: both arrows and famine strike from a distance, are deadly, and often inescapable for their targets
shared traits of lethality and directedness
conceptualization of famine as a weapon in God’s arsenal
posture: depicting God as a warrior launching famine as a weapon
heightening the terror of famine by framing it as a targeted assault
instances.explanation: Calling famine ‘arrows’ metaphorically depicts it as a set of lethal projectiles God shoots at those appointed for judgment.

instances.english_text: and [I] will break your staff of bread.
target: the removal of reliable food supply and sustenance
vehicle: a staff that one leans on, which is then broken
ground: bread/food functions as support of life just as a staff supports a person physically; breaking it removes stability and aid
shared idea of dependence on something for support
cognitive mapping of material support to physical prop
posture: emphasis on God actively removing the foundational supports of life
underscoring vulnerability when basic provision fails
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘break the staff of bread’ treats bread (food supply) as a staff that upholds life; breaking it metaphorically describes the collapse of sustenance and stability.

deliberation: The verse lists famine, wild beasts, pestilence, bloodshed, and sword—all standard covenant-curse agents. Though the catalog is stylized, each element is meant literally as a mode of judgment, and no distinct metaphor, idiom, or hyperbole emerges beyond this formulaic listing.
